[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]For more details, please consult the Default/Provisioning policy.[BR][/BR]

Title.Formula: "What level of management intensity is required for this relation?"

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR01C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 1. Competitive Position [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]A projects survival over the medium to long term depends first and foremost on its long term commercial viability and competitive position. We consider the degree of exposure to competition as well as the degree of competitiveness: How is the projects service or product placed from a cost perspective, location, technological advance, etc. Competition is not limited to the competition arising from similar assets but from all assets which serve a similar purpose.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY GOOD: Entrenched monopoly situation or very limited de facto competition for product/service over term of debt[BR][/BR]GOOD: Product or service exposed to some competition but product or service has solid entrenched competitive position in the served market(s). Position is stable over time. OR: product/service provided is not in top competitive position but highly rated offtaker of product/service can pass on cost to its own customers (e.g. by regulation) without any question and adverse consequence.[BR][/BR]MEDIUM: Project provides competitive or discretionary product/service. Product/service is expected to be in an above average to average position, or level of competition may change over time but not drastically.[BR][/BR]POOR: Asset is exposed to broad competition, Competitive position is average to somewhat weak, and/or could change materially over time[BR][/BR]VERY POOR: Asset and/or end product is fully exposed to competition, competitive position is untested, uncertain or weak.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Is there a monopoly situation? [BR][/BR]Consider Porters 5 forces (new entrants, substitute products, suppliers power, customers power and competitive arena)[BR][/BR]

Title.Formula: "2. Industry Logic, Alignment of Economic Interests"

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR02C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Template: 1:Very Low Risk|2:Low Risk|3:Medium Risk|4:High Risk|5:Very High Risk|
PresentationVariable.Hint: 2. Industry Logic, Alignment of Economic Interests[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Industrial logic: Is there a demonstrated need for the projects service/product and the end product. Alignment of economic interests: Do all key contracts make sense for all key parties in the industrial chain as to price, rights and obligations.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY LOW RISK: Long term viability is not in doubt: Essential asset to the community. All interests very well aligned (e.g. only General Hospital in region)[BR][/BR]LOW RISK: Asset important to the functioning of the community, All interests well aligned[BR][/BR]MEDIUM RISK: Industrial logic is solid, key parties interests are generally well aligned or there could be some mis-alignment but the parties can be easily replaced with little negative impact on the project [BR][/BR]HIGH RISK: Industrial logic is average and debatable under some scenarios, key parties interests not entirely aligned but risk is manageable[BR][/BR]VERY HIGH RISK: Discretionary product, industrial logic is questionable, several of the key parties interests are mis-aligned[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]What are the main counterparties in the projects service/product?[BR][/BR]To what degree the projects service/product is necessary to the them?[BR][/BR]To what degree all counterparties interests are aligned?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR03C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 3. Predictability of net cash flows[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Assessed by the degree of exposure to movements in price and volume for both revenues and costs and by the nature and extent of any mismatch between costs and revenues. Borrowers cash flows and volatility profile in comparison to industry earnings volatility and to its peers. This should take into account the impact of external factors common to the industry, sources of revenue, diversification, stability of supply chain. Cyclicality in revenues or costs as well as volatility in any of the underlying should also be considered.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY HIGH: Cash flows are highly predictable and stable. Any volatility has been hedged or mitigated.[BR][/BR]HIGH: Cash flows are predictable and stable. Some volatility may occur with a very low probability and some mitigation may be in place.[BR][/BR]MEDIUM: Cash flows are reasonably predictable and stable. Some volatility may exist but no major fluctuations are expected.[BR][/BR]LOW: Cash flows are somewhat unpredictable. There is little or insufficient mitigation in place.[BR][/BR]VERY LOW: Cash flows are highly unpredictable and there is no mitigation in place.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Is the company exposed to movements in price and volume? If so how do they impact costs and revenues?[BR][/BR]How do movements in price and volume impact cost and revenues of peer companies?[BR][/BR]Are there measures to mitigate the effects of volatility in place?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR04C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Template: 1:Very Low Risk|2:Low Risk|3:Medium Risk|4:High Risk|5:Very High Risk|
PresentationVariable.Hint: 4. Operating Complexity / Technology[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Complexity, technology and operating risks can lead to material weakening of a project. In a single asset project, if revenue generating capacity is disrupted because of operational problems, there is no alternative source of cash flows to meet debt service requirements unless specific liquidity has been set aside in sufficient amounts to deal with the likely delays.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Process/technology complexity issues to be considered are not purely technological but may include other factors such as:[BR][/BR] Difficulty in timely procurement of resources and training of staff[BR][/BR] Interdependency of process steps with potential for knock-on effects[BR][/BR] Ease of distribution of goods or supply of services[BR][/BR] Complex approval process / regulatory systems[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY LOW RISK: Simple commercially proven process/technology with minimal complexity.[BR][/BR]LOW RISK: Commercially proven process/technology with some or little complexity.[BR][/BR]MEDIUM RISK: Commercially proven process/technology but some operating challenges have occurred at the asset or for the asset type.[BR][/BR]HIGH RISK: Most of the process/technology considered proven and potentially complex to with certain elements that are untested or have limited operating history.[BR][/BR]VERY HIGH RISK: Process/technology largely unproven and complex. Where asset has had several years of operations, operating performance has been consistently well below industry standards.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Is the complexity of the process/technology understood?[BR][/BR]What is the track record? Similar process/technology in the Industry?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR05C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 5. Project Phase[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]The phase of the project is a risk driver as start-ups and companies with no history are more likely to Default. The construction phase also carries some extra risks.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Construction [BR][/BR]Launch[BR][/BR]Growth[BR][/BR]Stability[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]In what phase is the project?[BR][/BR]How long the project has been in place for?[BR][/BR]What is the annual revenue volatility?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR06C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 6. Event Risk[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Projects that are typically single asset entities are more exposed than conventional corporate issuers to various unexpected and uncontrollable events which could have a material effect on their performance, revenues and/or costs since they may have limited ability to meet increased costs or face reduced revenues. In the worst case scenario, such an event could be fatal for a project or, at a minimum, life changing. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY LOW: No exposure and/or fully mitigated through contracts, immediate compensation.[BR][/BR]LOW: Limited exposure and/or mitigated through contracts only subject to administrative procedures.[BR][/BR]MEDIUM: Potential material unmitigated exposures but with low probability or limited in size, Most events mitigated or covered by insurance or through contracts although payments may be subject to negotiations or some limits[BR][/BR]HIGH: Materially exposed to event risk and unclear or incomplete or untested provisions/mitigations.[BR][/BR]VERY HIGH: Material exposure little/no mitigation.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Are there mitigation measures, for example, insurance in place?[BR][/BR]Is the project dependent on a single asset?[BR][/BR]Regulation changes expected? Strikes? Force Majeure?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR07C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 7. Management Quality[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Assess the quality of the suppliers of the project, taking into consideration both qualitative and financial aspects. Management quality is a key driver of the financial strength of a Borrower. This factor considers relevant experience, track record, key person risk, etc.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY HIGH is associated with management teams with extensive experience (>20 years) and that have very successfully lead the Borrower through good and bad cycles. It is expected for the Borrower to have an excellent management structure with separated teams for the key functions (Ex: Marketing, Finance, Operations, Legal/Compliance) and layers of intermediate manager. This should be Borrowers not dependent on one individual or with a good succession plan in place.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]HIGH is associated with management teams with good experience (>10 years) and that have successfully lead the Borrower through good and bad cycles. It is expected for the Borrower to have a good management structure with separated teams for the key functions (Ex: Marketing, Finance, Operations, Legal/Compliance) and some layers of intermediate managers. This should be Borrowers not dependent on one individual or with a succession plan in place.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]MEDIUM is associated with management teams with reasonable experience (<10 years) and that have successfully lead the Borrower or management teams with longer experience but that had some difficulties leading the team through bad cycles. It is expected for the Borrower to have a reasonable management structure with some separate teams for any of the key functions (Ex: Marketing, Finance, Operations, Legal/Compliance) and some layers of intermediate managers. Borrowers with dependence on one individual and without a succession plan should not have a response better than medium.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]LOW is associated with management teams with limited experience (<5 years) and that have successfully lead the Company or management teams with longer experience but that had difficulties leading the company through bad cycles. This should be Borrowers with some dependence on one individual and without a good management structure to mitigate this risk.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY LOW is associated with management teams with very limited experience (<2 years) or management teams with longer experience but that are consistently having difficulties managing the Borrower and ensuring good financial results. This should be Borrowers highly dependent on one individual that is near retirement and without any succession plan should be classified in this category.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]How many years of experience does the management have in the industry?[BR][/BR]What is the track record of the management?[BR][/BR]What is the structure of the management? Do they depend on one individual?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR08C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 8. Management Relationship[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR]Refers to managements willingness to provide accurate and timely information as well as managements willingness and ability to cooperate with requests from your organization, such as requests for management information, audited accounts etc. [BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR]EXCELLENT: Borrower is of the highest standard and gives accurate feedback to the relationship manager even without being asked for information[BR][/BR]GOOD: Timely information given when it is requested by the relationship manager[BR][/BR]ADEQUATE: Minimum interaction but that is enough for a minimal control of the status of the project[BR][/BR]POOR: Borrower does not update the relationship manager on the status of the project[BR][/BR]NONEXISTENT: New client without track record or the borrower is blocking all enquiries[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR]For how long has the relationship with the company management been in place?[BR][/BR]Has the management changed in the meanwhile?[BR][/BR]Does the management provide all information requested (in a timely manner)? [BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR09C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 9. Financial Policy[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]The factors considered are the Borrowers desired capital structure, its financing, liquidity and hedging strategies and its proclivity for strategic changes, including acquisitions. Previous adherence to stated commitments, how cash flow has been used in the past are assessed, including the record of balancing shareholder and debt holder interests and level of caution in management of the Borrowers liquidity profile. Based on the understanding of past actions, the incentives and pressures on management and its strategic goals, a subjective forward looking view is formed about likely future performance. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]HIGHLY CONSERVATIVE - Expected to have a highly conservative financial policy with an ability and willingness to fund all requirements from internal sources. It is also expected for the Borrower to mitigate nearly all of the exchange risk via hedging contracts. The Borrower considers as a strategic objective maintaining a good credit rating with the Banks.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]CONSERVATIVE - Expected to have a conservative and balanced financial policy with an ability and willingness to fund main requirements from internal sources. Most of the exchange risk is mitigated via hedging. The Borrower regards a good rating as important but not a strategic objective.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]BALANCED - Expected to have a balanced financial policy however with potential for the use of internal cash flows to either make acquisitions or pay the Shareholders. The exchange risk is only partial hedged representing a potential source of risk.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]RISKY - Expected to have a financial policy that is unfavourable to creditors. Alternate sources of liquidity are limited, or might even be unavailable, bank credit facilities maybe be fully secured with just with covenant cushion. Exchange risk is not correctly mitigated and any negative movement in the relevant exchange rates might place the Borrower into financial problems. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY RISKY - Expected to have financial policies, either by making acquisitions or activity expansions using most of the funds available and by remunerating the shareholders without ensuring a good level of liquidity, that could contribute to a high likelihood of Default. Exchange risk is not correctly mitigated and any negative movement in the relevant exchange rates might place the Borrower into financial problems.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]How conservative is the policy in respect of the capital structure, its financing and liquidity?[BR][/BR]Is hedging used to mitigate relevant risks?[BR][/BR]How much of available funds are used for expansion and acquisitions? [BR][/BR]How much important is a good rating for a borrower?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR10C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 10. Conduct of [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]This is the track record of the client relationship. This includes factors such as openness, timeliness of information, payment history, track record of keeping to promised plans/targets. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]GOOD: Creditor payments are made on a normal timescale and/or there have been no checks dishonoured within the past 2 years. [BR][/BR]ACCEPTABLE: All breaches have been less than 2.5% of the value specified in the covenant or loan or account terms, and these have been rectified within three months of occurring.[BR][/BR]NO EXPERIENCE: No breaches of terms, but the borrower has been a customer for less than one year (and you do not have details of any previous business banking).[BR][/BR]POOR: The account works within a tight balance range (this could be a sign that creditor payments are only made once monies are received, a significant warning signal) and/or checks have been dishonoured within the past 2 years.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]How timely the payments were made? What is track record of meeting plans and targets?[BR][/BR]Have there been any covenant or loan term breaches?[BR][/BR]How many years of history with the customer?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR11C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 11. Credit History[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]This is the track record of payment history with all creditors. This may be viewed as an external evaluation of the borrowers credit history and includes all external and internal sources which provide information regarding the credit history. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]CLEAR if the business has been operational for at least one year, credit records are available, and no problems have been recorded on any of the external sources that you use to check a potential borrowers credit worthiness.[BR][/BR]NO EXPERIENCE: The customers record is clear, but less than one years information is available. [BR][/BR]MINOR PROBLEMS if the customer has had problems (short of bankruptcy), but such problems have not occurred in the last five years. [BR][/BR]PREVIOUSLY BANKRUPT: The customer has declared bankruptcy in the past (>2y ago), and has emerged from bankruptcy with only minor problems (as defined above).[BR][/BR]MAJOR PROBLEMS/BANKRUPT if the customer is bankrupt or has had significant problems with external creditors or others to which it owes money. Several returned checks (more than two over the last two years) or an adverse legal judgment would indicate major problems. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]How long the business has been operational? How much historical information is available?[BR][/BR]Have there been any problems, if so, when?[BR][/BR]Has the obligor been bankrupt? When?[BR][/BR]

Title.Formula: "12. Confidence in Financial Information, Transparency / Quality of Information"

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR12C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 12. Confidence in Financial Information, Transparency / Quality of Information[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Confidence in Financial Information refers to the quality of the financial information available for assessment. It is not unusual for a small business to have both partial and dated accounting information. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY HIGH: This response should represent the case of a Borrower with financial statements audited by a big international audit firm and without any qualification. The Borrower should also send the Financial Information to the Bank as soon as the information is readily available and including detailed information (For example the General Ledger). It is also expected for the firm to respond to any queries from the bank in a very timely fashion while sharing internal strategic documents as for example a multi-year business plan.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]HIGH: This response should represent the case of a Borrower with financial statements audited by a local audit firm and without any qualification. The Borrower should also send the Financial Information to the Bank as soon as the information is readily available and including detailed information (For example the General Ledger). It is also expected for the firm to respond to any queries from the bank in a very timely fashion while sharing some internal documents.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]MEDIUM: This response should represent the case of a Borrower with financial statements audited by a chartered accountant and without any qualification. The Borrower should also send the Financial Information to the Bank in a short time frame and including some detailed information. It is also expected for the firm to respond to any queries from the bank in a reasonable timely fashion but there is no sharing of internal documents.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]LOW: This response should represent the case of a Borrower with financial statements simply approved by the Tax Office. The Borrower normally delays the delivery of financial information and provides little or no detailed information. The Borrower ignores some of the queries from the bank and there is no sharing of internal documents.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY LOW: This response should represent the case of a Borrower with financial statements prepared by the Borrower. The Borrower ignores most of the queries from the bank and there is no sharing of internal documents. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Who audited the financial statements? [BR][/BR]How timely and how detailed information is sent? Are internal documents shared with the bank? Timely response to queries?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR13C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 13. Access to funds[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]This question relates to overall capacity of the firm to access funds either for day-to-day activities or for investment financing. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY HIGH: A Borrower ranking Very High is expected to have the full support from the owners, either via a personal guarantee or any other equivalent sort of commitment or proven past experience of support, that have a considerable amount of net worth (should cover at least 30% of total credit). It is also expected for the Borrower to have a relation with more than 4 banks and have a considerable available credit limit in the banking system (enough to cover 1/2 of the operational costs for one year).[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]HIGH: A Borrower ranking High is expected to have the full support from the owners, either via a personal guarantee or any other equivalent sort of commitment or proven past experience of support, that have a considerable amount of net worth (should cover at least 20% of total credit). It is also expected for the Borrower to have a relation with more than 2 banks and have a good available credit limit in the banking system (enough to cover 1/4 of the operational costs for one year).[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]MEDIUM: A Borrower ranking Medium is expected to have the support from the owners that have a considerable amount of net worth (should cover at least 10% of total credit). It is also expected for the Borrower to have a relation with more than 1 bank and have a reasonable available credit limit in the banking system (enough to cover 1/6 of the operational costs for one year).[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]LOW: A Borrower ranking Low is expected to have the low support from the owners that have a reduced amount of net worth (less than 10% of total credit). The borrower typically will have limited access to banks and a very reduced amount of credit limit still available.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY LOW: A Borrower ranking Very Low is expected to not have any support from the owner (look at past history for evidence of lack of support). The borrower had several banks cancelling on the credit lines on the last months. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Does the borrower have full support from the owners? Is there a personal guarantee or any other equivalent sort of commitment or proven past experience of support?[BR][/BR]How many banks does the borrower have a relationship with?[BR][/BR]What is the available credit of the borrower?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR14C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 14. DSCR[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]DSCR = Cash flow available for debt service / Scheduled interest plus principal payments[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]The Debt Service Coverage Ratio is defined as Cash Flow Available for Debt Service (CFADS) divided by the scheduled interest and principal payments as measured during any given period (annual DSCR where derived on a twelve month rolling basis).[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]CFADS is defined as cash flow from operations in any given period less major maintenance capital expenditures (all measured after tax but before interest payment). [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Scheduled Interest & Principal Payments - the scheduled interest and principal payments as defined in the projects bond indenture or loan agreement during the specified period (i.e. excluding any cash sweeps).[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]For projects in the construction/launch phase the DSCR should reflect an average of the expected future annual cash flows. In a stable operating phase, where there the DSCR will be stable from year to year, it can be used the last available calculation.[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR15C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 15. Fund from Operations / Total Debt[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Measures the level of cash flows generated by the project that would be available to support its debt load.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Funds from Operations (FFO): FFO is defined as the cash flow available for debt service (CFADS) of a project less interest payments based on a projects cash flow forecast model. The FFO to debt ratio is measured on the basis of annualized cash flows (twelve month rolling FFO) to total debt adjusted for leases.[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR16C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 16. Cash Ratio[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Cash Ratio = Cash & Equivalents / Current Liabilities[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Liquidity is the ability to have sufficient funds on hand to pay bills or short term obligations when they are due and to meet unexpected needs for cash.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o Cash & Equivalents: represents any directly transferable medium of exchange. This item includes legal tender and amount due by banks also as items such as Checks, postal orders, and bank credit card vouchers.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o Current Liabilities: are defined as all obligations which are due in the next year. The Amounts payable within one year should comprise the sub-headings Current portion of amounts payable after one year, Financial debts (<1year), Trade debts (<1year), Advances received on contracts in progress (<1year), Taxes, remuneration and social security and the Other amounts payable. [BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR17C_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Template: 1:Very Low Risk|2:Low Risk|3:Medium Risk|4:High Risk|5:Very High Risk|
PresentationVariable.Hint: 17. Break Even Analysis[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Testing the resilience of the project to decrease revenues and/or increased costs and/or other relevant risks which could have a major negative effect on the issuers credit metrics. Since the methodology is applicable to a wide range of projects no specific threshold is prescribed and as a result, a qualitative assessment is performed. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY LOW RISK: DSCR of 1.0 or break even reached only under very strenuous decrease of price/volume and/or cost increases.[BR][/BR]LOW RISK: DSCR of 1.0 or break even reached only under material level of stress in price, volume or costs.[BR][/BR]MEDIUM RISK: DSCR of 1.0 or break even reached under material but fairly conventional level of stress in price, volume or costs.[BR][/BR]HIGH RISK: DSCR of 1.0 or break even reached under limited level of stress in price, volume or costs.[BR][/BR]VERY HIGH RISK: Little to no resilience. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]In what conditions (costs change, revenues change) can the Break Even be reached?[BR][/BR]Are those conditions likely? What is the previous track record?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: Notch01C
PresentationVariable.Hint: Refinancing Risk[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]The existence of a mitigating project financing structure can in some cases lead to a notching up or down of the borrower. However, in most cases, the presence of all standard provisions are not expected to result in any material adjustment either way. This factor may include equity injections, ring fencing, covenant package, ownership structure, underlying contractual arrangements, etc.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Downgrade by 2[BR][/BR]Downgrade by 1[BR][/BR]No notch[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]What is the financing structure of the company?[BR][/BR]Is the financing structure of the company sustainable in the near future?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: Notch02C
PresentationVariable.Hint: Construction Risk[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Possibility to adjust the final rating for any additional construction risk not captured by the above factors. This may include: Raw construction risk (including management, subcontractor, guarantees), EPC Contract, Liquidity & Monitoring, Technology. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Downgrade by 3[BR][/BR]Downgrade by 2[BR][/BR]Downgrade by 1[BR][/BR]No notch[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Is there any construction related risk that has not been captured? [BR][/BR]What is the track record of the construction company and subcontractors? [BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: Notch03C
PresentationVariable.Hint: Management Integrity and Change/Resignation[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Possibility to adjust the final rating for any serious doubts or question marks over the integrity of the management or owner, as well as any imminent changes in management or management structure, and high management turnover, which are not captured in the management factors. May in some circumstances also be positive (e.g. low-performing manager being replaced by a respected industry figure).[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Downgrade by 2[BR][/BR]Downgrade by 1[BR][/BR]No notch[BR][/BR]Upgrade by 1[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR]Have there been any changes recently in the management or management structure?[BR][/BR]Are there any doubts about the integrity of the management?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: Notch04C
PresentationVariable.Hint: Group and Owner Support[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Possibility to adjust the final rating for any serious doubts or question marks over level of financial commitment and additional financial support that the owners or the Group are able to provide to the business, which are not captured in the management factors. This indicates the owners commitment and trust in the business model support. This may also provide a cushion against bankruptcy in times of adversity and may therefore reduce the likelihood of a Default.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Downgrade by 2[BR][/BR]Downgrade by 1[BR][/BR]No notch[BR][/BR]Upgrade by 1[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]How likely is the support from the Group or the Owners?[BR][/BR]How much of additional financial support can the borrower expect from the Group or the Owners if needed?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: Notch05C
PresentationVariable.Hint: Possibility to adjust the final rating if there are no (audited) financials available or if the financial information is insufficient to assess the financial risks. 0 = all information is available and sufficient, 1 = the available information is insufficient to assess the risks, 2 = no information available at all. When using this notching factor, it should be clearly explained why it is applied and which information is insufficient (if any).

PresentationVariable.Name: DefaultC
PresentationVariable.Hint: Default in Basel II[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Possibility to adjust the final rating to reflect a Default. Defaults have been recognized when either or both of the following have taken place:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]a. The obligor is past due more than 90 days on any material credit obligation to Triodos Bank. Amounts considered material are larger or equal than 500 EUR. [BR][/BR]b. Triodos Bank is of the opinion that the customer will fail to repay its obligations to the banking group in full, without recourse by the bank to actions such as realizing security. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]For more details, please consult the Default/Provisioning policy.[BR][/BR]

Title.Formula: "What level of management intensity is required for this relation?"

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR01D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 1. Market Reputation[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]The perceived value of an institutions programs and services determines its reputation and brand value. A strong market reputation and brand drive in institutions ability to attract clients, staff, board members, government support and gifts. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Excellent[BR][/BR]Strong[BR][/BR]Average[BR][/BR]Weak[BR][/BR]Very Weak[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]What are the latest news on the company? How do they impact the companys reputation?[BR][/BR]Historically, how has the company reputation been? [BR][/BR]

Title.Formula: "2. Demand measured by long term trends"

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR02D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Template: 1:Excellent Outlook|2:Good Outlook|3:Stable Outlook|4:Poor Outlook|5:Very Poor Outlook|
PresentationVariable.Hint: 2. Demand measured by long term trends[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]This factor looks at a number of measures to determine the strength of demand for an institutions exhibits or programs and fluctuations in both short and long-term trends. Size is defined here as the number of potential clients within a segment of the overall market. Increased size corresponds to a larger number of clients being classified within the target segment (e.g. growth of existing cultural/interest groups). Scope is defined here as the number of demographic sectors within the target audience of the institution. Increased scope corresponds to the increased appeal of the product/services to new audience groups (e.g. wider appeal of the product/services to groups previously not part of the target audience).[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]EXCELLENT OUTLOOK: The target demographic is expected to grow in size AND scope.[BR][/BR]GOOD OUTLOOK: The target demographic is expected to grow in size OR scope.[BR][/BR]STABLE OUTLOOK: The target demographic is not expected to change significantly.[BR][/BR]POOR OUTLOOK: The target demographic in the target market is shrinking in size OR scope.[BR][/BR]VERY POOR OUTLOOK: The target demographic in the target market is shrinking in size AND scope.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]How many potential clients are there within a segment?[BR][/BR]How many demographic sectors are there within the target audience of the institution?[BR][/BR]What are the expected trends?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR03D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Template: 1:Very Low Risk|2:Low Risk|3:Medium Risk|4:High Risk|5:Very High Risk|
PresentationVariable.Hint: 3. Importance to Community[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]An institution which is deeply integrated into the community and/or provides a vital services is less likely to suffer from a withdrawal of donations, subsidies or government support. Additionally, projects or institutions which are important to the community or local government may be supported if they run into financial problems thus lowering the probability of default. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY LOW RISK: Long term viability is not in doubt: Essential asset to the community. All interests very well aligned[BR][/BR]LOW RISK: Asset important to the functioning of the community, All interests well aligned[BR][/BR]MEDIUM RISK: Industrial logic is solid, key parties interests are generally well aligned or there could be some mis-alignment but the parties can be easily replaced with little negative impact on the project[BR][/BR]HIGH RISK: Industrial logic is average and debatable under some scenarios, key parties interests not entirely aligned but risk is manageable[BR][/BR]VERY HIGH RISK: Discretionary product, industrial logic is questionable, several of the key parties interests are mis-aligned[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Is the company relevant for the community?[BR][/BR]Are the companys interests aligned with the communitys ones?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR04D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 4. Fund Raising[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Historical fundraising prowess can be a powerful indicator of future fundraising success. To determine the strength of an institutions fundraising program, we look at the strategy of the development team and its track record during previous capital campaigns as well as sources of support, membership base, diversification of donors, etc. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY HIGH: The institution has a long track record of successful fundraising and an extensive support/membership base from which regular donations are received.[BR][/BR]HIGH: The institution has a track record of successful fundraising and a support/membership base from which regular donations are received.[BR][/BR]MEDIUM: The institution has a track record of past fundraising and a support/membership base from which donations are received periodically.[BR][/BR]LOW: The institution has little or no track record of past fundraising and there is no significant support/membership base or few regular donations. [BR][/BR]VERY LOW: The institution has no track record of fundraising or regular donations.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Does the company receive regular donations?[BR][/BR]How strong is the companys fund raising track record?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR05D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 5. Cash Flow Predictability[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Borrowers earnings and volatility profile in comparison to industry earnings volatility and to its peers, impact of external factors common to the industry, sources of revenue, diversification, stability of supply chain. Cyclicality in revenues or costs as well as volatility in any of the underlying should also be considered. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY HIGH: Cash flows are highly predictable and stable. Any volatility has been hedged or mitigated.[BR][/BR]HIGH: Cash flows are predictable and stable. Some volatility may occur with a very low probability and some mitigation may be in place.[BR][/BR]MEDIUM: Cash flows are reasonably predictable and stable. Some volatility may exist but no major fluctuations are expected.[BR][/BR]LOW: Cash flows are somewhat unpredictable. There is little or insufficient mitigation in place.[BR][/BR]VERY LOW: Cash flows are highly unpredictable and there is no mitigation in place.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]What are Cash Flows drivers? [BR][/BR]Is the company Cash Flow predictable and stable? [BR][/BR]Are there any mitigation measures in place?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR06D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 6. Complexity of Operations[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Complexity, technology and operating risks can lead to material weakening of a project. In a single asset project, if revenue generating capacity is disrupted because of operational problems, there is no alternative source of cash flows to meet debt service requirements unless specific liquidity has been set aside in sufficient amounts to deal with the likely delays. This may translate into reduced or disrupted revenues, increased operating costs, increased capital expenditures, etc.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Complexity issues to be considered are not purely technological but may include other factors such as:[BR][/BR] Difficulty in timely procurement of resources and training of staff[BR][/BR] Interdependency of process steps with potential for knock-on effects[BR][/BR] Ease of distribution of goods or supply of services[BR][/BR] Complex approval process / regulatory systems. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY LOW: Simple commercially proven process/technology with minimal complexity[BR][/BR]LOW: Commercially proven process/technology with some or little complexity.[BR][/BR]MEDIUM: Commercially proven process/technology but some operating challenges have occurred at the asset or for the asset type.[BR][/BR]HIGH: Most of the process/technology considered proven and potentially complex to with certain elements that are untested or have limited operating history.[BR][/BR]VERY HIGH: Process/technology largely unproven and complex. Where asset has had several years of operations, operating performance has been consistently well below industry standards.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Is the complexity of the process/technology understood?[BR][/BR]Is technology a main driver of the company?[BR][/BR]What kind of impact do process delays/new regulation have?[BR][/BR]

Title.Formula: "7. Management and Board Structure, Composition and Commitment"

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR07D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 7. Management and Board Structure, Composition and Commitment[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Board members and senior leadership must balance a the projects aims over the long-term with the need to manage financial resources in a way that ensures continued viability and play a vital role in fundraising. The board may also provide additional commitment and financial support. Furthermore management quality is a key driver of the financial strength of a Borrower therefore this factor considers relevant experience, track record, key person risk, etc. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY HIGH: The board members are highly experienced in the relevant sector. The board will have a long track record of successful fundraising. The board contains a diverse mix of members and the board is fully committed to support the institution. Management teams with extensive experience (>20 years) and that have very successfully lead the Borrower through good and bad cycles. It is expected for the Borrower to have an excellent management structure with separated teams for the key functions (Ex: Marketing, Finance, Operations, Legal/Compliance) and layers of intermediate manager. This should be Borrowers not dependent on one individual or with a good succession plan in place.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]HIGH: The board members are experienced in the relevant sector. The board will have a track record of successful fundraising. The board contains a mix of members and the board is committed to support the institution. Management teams with good experience (>10 years) and that have successfully lead the Borrower through good and bad cycles. It is expected for the Borrower to have a good management structure with separated teams for the key functions (Ex: Marketing, Finance, Operations, Legal/Compliance) and some layers of intermediate managers. This should be Borrowers not dependent on one individual or with a succession plan in place.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]MEDIUM: Most board members are experienced in the relevant sector. The board will have a track record of past fundraising. The board contains a mix of members to some degree. It is committed to support the institution but may not be able to provide additional assistance. Management teams with reasonable experience (<10 years) and that have successfully lead the Borrower or management teams with longer experience but that had some difficulties leading the team through bad cycles. It is expected for the Borrower to have a reasonable management structure with some separate teams for any of the key functions (Ex: Marketing, Finance, Operations, Legal/Compliance) and some layers of intermediate managers. Borrowers with dependence on one individual and without a succession plan should not have a response better than medium.[BR][/BR]LOW: Few members have experience in the relevant sector. The board will have some or little track record of past fundraising. The board does not contain a mixture of skills or is highly dependent on key persons. It shows little commitment to the institution. Management teams with limited experience (<5 years) and that have successfully lead the Company or management teams with longer experience but that had difficulties leading the company through bad cycles. This should be Borrowers with some dependence on one individual and without a good management structure to mitigate this risk.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY LOW: Few or no board members have experience in the relevant sector. The board will have no track record of fundraising. There is no notable commitment to the institution. Management teams with very limited experience (<2 years) or management teams with longer experience but that are consistently having difficulties managing the Borrower and ensuring good financial results. This should be Borrowers highly dependent on one individual that is near retirement and without any succession plan should be classified in this category.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]How much experience do board members have?[BR][/BR]Does the board have a track record of successful fundraising?[BR][/BR]How many years of experience does the management have?[BR][/BR]Does the company depend on one individual?[BR][/BR]Are key functions in the company separated?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR08D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 8. Government Relations[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]The relationship with government and/or the community is perhaps paramount due to the potential to restrict access to capital, reduce tax subsidies, increase regulatory oversight. Continued support, both financial and operational can be credit positive. While governmental financial support generally comes with certain conditions and expectations, it can strengthen the credit quality. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Positive indicators of government relations can include:[BR][/BR] Political autonomy from the state in key areas, including ability to set prices, determine distribution of good/services, retain surpluses, manage investment[BR][/BR] Consistent state financial support for operations and capital projects, particularly during times the state is experiencing economic challenges[BR][/BR] Evidence of stable and supportive relationships with the local community including lack of contentious debate or proposals over local taxes[BR][/BR] Substantial local/regional economic impact of the institution[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]EXCELLENT: Extensive direct government support including subsidies, aid, etc. with full political autonomy.[BR][/BR]GOOD: Some government support through supportive legal/regulatory framework, subsidies, etc. Some degree of autonomy may be lost due to covenants.[BR][/BR]AVERAGE: Government is in favour of institution but does not provide active support.[BR][/BR]POOR: Some negative government controls (e.g. obstructive legal/regulatory framework) are in place and the government does not aim to support the institution.[BR][/BR]VERY POOR: Punitive or obstructive government measures exist with no support for the institution.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Does the government directly support the company?[BR][/BR]Is the company politically autonomous from the government?[BR][/BR]Are there negative regulatory framework or legal impositions?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR09D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 9. Oversight and Disclosure Practices[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Clearly articulated policies and division of responsibilities provide transparency, accountability, and oversight. In addition to internal management, external public disclosure of policies, budgeting practices, projections, and long-term plans help ensure accountability to key stakeholders.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Positive indicators of oversight and disclosure practices include:[BR][/BR] Board approved policies on investments, debt, liquidity, and conflicts of interest[BR][/BR] Detailed disclosure and transparency for internal decision makers and external stakeholders[BR][/BR] Appropriate staffing for effective implementation of policies[BR][/BR] Frequent board oversight of the president, including annual performance assessment by multiple board members who rotate over time[BR][/BR] Use of internal audit function that reports to the board[BR][/BR] Detailed disclosure on university website regarding student outcomes, financial statements, research activity, budgets, compliance with bond covenants, and other material issues[BR][/BR] Filing of financial statements within 90 days of the fiscal year end, including detailed management discussion and analysis[BR][/BR] Government regulation and oversight of practices[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Excellent[BR][/BR]Above Average[BR][/BR]Average[BR][/BR]Poor[BR][/BR]Very Poor[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Are internal decision disclosed to external stakeholders in a detailed and timely manner?[BR][/BR]Is staffing appropriate for the effective implementation of policies?[BR][/BR]Are financial statements filled in in a timely manner?[BR][/BR]Does the president frequently oversight the board?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR10D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 10. Financial Policy[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]The factors considered are the Borrowers desired capital structure, its financing, liquidity and hedging strategies and its tendency for strategic changes, including acquisitions. Previous adherence to stated commitments, how cash flow has been used in the past are assessed, including the record of balancing shareholder and debt holder interests and level of caution in management of the Borrowers liquidity profile. Based on the understanding of past actions, the incentives and pressures on management and its strategic goals, a subjective forward looking view is formed about likely future performance.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]HIGHLY CONSERVATIVE - Expected to have a highly conservative financial policy with an ability and willingness to fund all requirements from internal sources. It is also expected for the Borrower to mitigate nearly all of the exchange risk via hedging contracts. The Borrower considers as a strategic objective maintaining a good credit rating with the Banks.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]CONSERVATIVE - Expected to have a conservative and balanced financial policy with an ability and willingness to fund main requirements from internal sources. Most of the exchange risk is mitigated via hedging. The Borrower regards a good rating as important but not a strategic objective.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]BALANCED - Expected to have a balanced financial policy however with potential for the use of internal cash flows to either make acquisitions or pay the Shareholders. The exchange risk is only partial hedged representing a potential source of risk.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]RISKY - Expected to have a financial policy that is unfavorable to creditors. Alternate sources of liquidity are limited, or might even be unavailable, bank credit facilities maybe be fully secured with just with covenant cushion. Exchange risk is not correctly mitigated and any negative movement in the relevant exchange rates might place the Borrower into financial problems. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]VERY RISKY - Expected to have financial policies, either by making acquisitions or activity expansions using most of the funds available and by remunerating the shareholders without ensuring a good level of liquidity, that could contribute to a high likelihood of default. Exchange risk is not correctly mitigated and any negative movement in the relevant exchange rates might place the Borrower into financial problems.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]How conservative is the policy in respect of the capital structure, its financing and liquidity?[BR][/BR]Is hedging used to mitigate relevant risks?[BR][/BR]How much of available funds are used for expansion and acquisitions? [BR][/BR]How much important is a good rating for a borrower?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR11D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 11. Conduct of Account[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]This is the track record of the client relationship. This includes factors such as openness, timeliness of information, payment history, track record of keeping to promised plans/targets. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]GOOD: Creditor payments are made on a normal timescale and/or there have been no checks dishonoured within the past 2 years. [BR][/BR]ACCEPTABLE: All breaches have been less than 2.5% of the value specified in the covenant or loan or account terms, and these have been rectified within three months of occurring.[BR][/BR]NO EXPERIENCE: No breaches of terms, but the borrower has been a customer for less than one year (and you do not have details of any previous business banking).[BR][/BR]POOR: The account works within a tight balance range (this could be a sign that creditor payments are only made once monies are received, a significant warning signal) and/or checks have been dishonoured within the past 2 years.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]How timely the payments were made? What is track record of meeting plans and targets?[BR][/BR]Have there been any covenant or loan term breaches?[BR][/BR]How many years of history with the customer?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR12D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 12. Credit History[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]This is the track record of payment history with all creditors. This may be viewed as an external evaluation of the borrowers credit history and includes all external and internal sources which provide information regarding the credit history. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]CLEAR if the business has been operational for at least one year, credit records are available, and no problems have been recorded on any of the external sources that you use to check a potential borrowers credit worthiness.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]NO EXPERIENCE: The customers record is clear, but less than one years information is available. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]MINOR PROBLEMS if the customer has had problems (short of bankruptcy), but such problems have not occurred in the last five years.[BR][/BR] [BR][/BR]PREVIOUSLY BANKRUPT: The customer has declared bankruptcy in the past (>2y ago), and has emerged from bankruptcy with only minor problems (as defined above).[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]MAJOR PROBLEMS/BANKRUPT if the customer is bankrupt or has had significant problems with external creditors or others to which it owes money. Several returned checks (more than two over the last two years) or an adverse legal judgment would indicate major problems.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]How long the business has been operational? How much historical information is available?[BR][/BR]Have there been any problems, if so, when?[BR][/BR]Has the obligor been bankrupt? When?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR13D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 13. EBITDA / Interest Expense[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]The Debt Coverage is of particular importance when determining the financial strength of companies, given the potential for cash flow volatility. For many companies, strong and stable cash flow to debt ratios are the best indicators of a healthy credit profile and can also be a competitive advantage by providing greater strategic and financial flexibility during cyclical downturns.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o EBITDA: EBIT + Depreciation and Amortisation[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o EBIT (Operating Profit): The Operating Profit (Loss) is a company's profit or loss derived from its operating activities, i.e. prior to its financial, extraordinary, or other income and charges.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o Depreciation and Amortisation: represents the amounts of economic benefit of all tangible and intangible fixed assets consumed in the financial year. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o Interest Expense: The item Interest and similar expenses represents finance costs of borrowing, inputted interest elements of financial leases, commitment fees in connection with obtaining credit facilities and the underwriting of a discount related to long-term provisions.[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR14D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 14. (Liabilities - (Cash & Securities)) / Assets[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Leverage is a simple way to compare the capital structures of companies. It also provides some insight into a companys financial policies, including its tolerance for debt levels.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o Cash & Marketable Securities: measures liquid assets which include cash at bank and in hand, as well as, short term financial investments (excluding short term own shares).[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o Total Assets: are the sum of the assets of a company.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o Total Liabilities: is the sum of current liabilities plus long-term debt.[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR15D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 15. Current Ratio[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Current Assets / Current Liabilities[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Liquidity is the ability to have sufficient funds on hand to pay bills or short term obligations when they are due and to meet unexpected needs for cash.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o Current Assets: Current assets include Cash at bank and in hand, Investments and other current assets that are not required for the long-term use. The Current Assets are the sum of the following headings: Accounts receivables, Stocks and contracts in progress, Investments, Cash at bank and in hand, Deferred charges and accrued income.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o Current Liabilities: are defined as all obligations which are due in the next year. The Amounts payable within one year should comprise the sub-headings Current portion of amounts payable after one year, Financial debts (<1year), Trade debts (<1year), Advances received on contracts in progress (<1year), Taxes, remuneration and social security and the Other amounts payable. [BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: VAR16D_ContributionSub1
PresentationVariable.Hint: 16. Cash Ratio[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Cash & Equivalents / Current Liabilities[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Liquidity is the ability to have sufficient funds on hand to pay bills or short term obligations when they are due and to meet unexpected needs for cash.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o Cash & Equivalents: represents any directly transferable medium of exchange. This item includes legal tender and amount due by banks also as items such as Checks, postal orders, and bank credit card vouchers.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]o Current Liabilities: are defined as all obligations which are due in the next year. The Amounts payable within one year should comprise the sub-headings Current portion of amounts payable after one year, Financial debts (<1year), Trade debts (<1year), Advances received on contracts in progress (<1year), Taxes, remuneration and social security and the Other amounts payable. [BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: Notch01D
PresentationVariable.Hint: Regulation[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Definition:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Changes in regulation that are expected to have a significant impact on the business, market and/or competitors.[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Response Clarification Text:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Downgrade by 2[BR][/BR]Downgrade by 1[BR][/BR]No notch[BR][/BR]Upgrade by 1[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Factor Evaluation Criteria:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Does the company operate in a highly regulated sector?[BR][/BR]Is the regulation expected to change?[BR][/BR]Does regulation have a relevant impact on the business?[BR][/BR]

PresentationVariable.Name: Notch02D
PresentationVariable.Hint: Possibility to adjust the final rating if there are no (audited) financials available or if the financial information is insufficient to assess the financial risks. 0 = all information is available and sufficient, 1 = the available information is insufficient to assess the risks, 2 = no information available at all. When using this notching factor, it should be clearly explained why it is applied and which information is insufficient (if any).

PresentationVariable.Name: DefaultD
PresentationVariable.Hint: Default in Basel II[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]Possibility to adjust the final rating to reflect a default. Defaults have been recognized when either or both of the following have taken place:[BR][/BR][BR][/BR]a. The obligor is past due more than 90 days on any material credit obligation to Triodos Bank. Amounts considered material are larger or equal than 500 EUR. [BR][/BR]b. Triodos Bank is of the opinion that the customer will fail to repay its obligations to the banking group in full, without recourse by the bank to actions such as realizing security. [BR][/BR][BR][/BR]For more details, please consult the Default/Provisioning policy.[BR][/BR]

Title.Formula: "What level of management intensity is required for this relation?"
"What level of management intensity is required for this relation?"
